definition[0]: part of a piece of furniture, such as a desk, that you pull out and push in and use to keep things in
note[0]: sock/cutlery drawer (=one for keeping socks, or knives, forks etc in)
example[0]: She took a file from her desk drawer.
example[1]: The scissors are in the kitchen drawer  (=drawer in a piece of kitchen furniture).
example[2]: He opened the top drawer of his desk, and took out a brown envelope.
example[3]: He opened the bottom drawer and got out a T-shirt.
example[4]: The passports are in my desk drawer.
example[5]: There's some string in that kitchen drawer.
example[6]: He hid the gun in his sock drawer.
example[7]: Have you looked in the left-hand drawer?
example[8]: Jonathan opened the drawer and took out a fork.
example[9]: He pulled open drawers until he found the papers.
example[10]: She shut the drawer and locked it with a small key.
example[11]: I've been through all my drawers and I can't find it.
example[12]: Someone had been in my bedroom and rummaged through my drawers.
definition[1]: a person who writes a cheque and so gives an instruction to his or her bank to pay a sum of money to someone
definition[2]: words written by a bank on a cheque that has not been paid, usually because there is not enough money in the account of the person who wrote it
definition[3]: a person who signs a BILL OF EXCHANGE that gives an instruction to another person to pay a sum of money at a particular time
